abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings indicate an unsatisfactory
            project outcome, unlikely sustainability, negligible
            institutional development impacts, and unsatisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. The unsuccessful
            project results draws many lessons, of which some follows.
            Specifically reinforced are issues concerning the critical
            aspects of: Bank responsiveness to the client needs,
            particularly legal documents related to restructuring
            amendments requested by the Government; maintaining a
            constant transparent dialogue with the client, to understand
            the reasons for certain decisions; clear Project design and
            objectives; and, personnel changes, that may affect the
            project in a negative way. Other lessons include the need
            for more flexible procurement and disbursement procedures,
            specifically for emergency operations. Conventional
            procurement and disbursement rules cannot be applied in a
            country, where agencies have no incentive to submit invoices
            or to identify eligible investments. Projects that finance
            small sub-projects should simplify financial management
            processes, especially those related to the validation of
            disbursements and expenditures. And, since very few
            countries are really prepared to engage in disaster risk
            management, the Bank should pay specific attention to this
            issue, and ramp up its efforts to train Bank staff, and
            Borrowers on this issue. Even though mitigation measures
            bring about major benefits, they have not been incorporated
            into the planning of sustainable development in countries
            repeatedly affected by disasters, such as the case in Mexico.
